title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: outlines propose change fireexposuR. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("heyairf/fireexposuR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to fireexposuR
text: Please note fireexposuR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Local scale example
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT basic example shows workflow assess wildfire exposure community using multiple functions fireexposuR package. package automates methods within various research products can accessed following links: Beverly et al. 2010 Beverly et al. 2021 Beverly Forbes 2023
code: library(fireexposuR)

title: Local scale example
text: First, example data generated imaginary town somewhere middle Alberta. hazardous fuel information reflective area, area interest actual community.
code: # load terra for spatial data funtions library(terra) #> terra 1.8.5  # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # read example polygon geometry for area of interest boundary geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # use geometry to make an area of interest polygon aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)  # generate random points within the aoi to represent values points <- terra::spatSample(aoi, 200)

title: Local scale example
text: hazard layer binary raster represents wildland fuels able generate long-range embers transmission distance 500 meters:

what: Area of interest and values data
title: Local scale example
text: aoi layer polygon representing boundary built environment imaginary town. points feature represents values within community. pretend points locations structures.

title: Local scale example
text: Now, use hazard data compute exposure long-range ember transmission.
code: library(fireexposuR) exposure <- fire_exp(hazard, tdist = "l") #> Warning in rgl.init(initValue, onlyNULL): RGL: unable to open X11 display #> Warning: 'rgl.init' failed, will use the null device. #> See '?rgl.useNULL' for ways to avoid this warning.

title: Local scale example
text: exposure raster rest package functions can used visualize different ways. landscape, can map exposure continuous scale fire_exp_map_cont():  can also see exposure distributed within built environment exposure classifications area interest fire_exp_map_class().  map gives us better understanding areas town fire entry points. can also summarize area fire_exp_summary() want know proportional distributions class. also data values within built environment, can map summarize table well.
code: fire_exp_map_cont(exposure) fire_exp_map_class(exposure, classify = "local", aoi) fire_exp_summary(exposure, classify = "local", aoi) #>      class npixels        prop  aream2 areaha #> 1      Nil       2 0.002372479   20000      2 #> 2      Low      33 0.039145907  330000     33 #> 3 Moderate     102 0.120996441 1020000    102 #> 4     High     132 0.156583630 1320000    132 #> 5  Extreme     574 0.680901542 5740000    574 # extract exposure to the points feature points_ext <- fire_exp_extract(exposure, points)  # visualize the extracted data in a summary table  fire_exp_extract_vis(points_ext, classify = "local") #>   scale method    class   n  prop #> 1 local  Point      Nil   1 0.005 #> 2 local  Point      Low   7 0.035 #> 3 local  Point Moderate  21 0.105 #> 4 local  Point     High  30 0.150 #> 5 local  Point  Extreme 141 0.705  # visualize the extracted data in a map fire_exp_extract_vis(points_ext, classify = "local", map = TRUE)

title: Local scale example
text: make believe town may also wish assess directional vulnerability wildfire towards community. assessment identifies linear pathways exposure landscape toward value.
code: # assess directional vulnerability transects <- fire_exp_dir(exposure, aoi)  # visualize directional vulnerability with a map fire_exp_dir_map(transects, aoi)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Air Forbes. Author, maintainer. Jennifer Beverly. Thesis advisor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Forbes , Beverly JL (2024). fireexposuR: Compute Visualize Wildfire Exposure. R Package version xxx, https://github.com/heyairf/fireexposuR.
code: @Manual{fireexposuR,   title = {fireexposuR: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure},   author = {Air M. Forbes and Jennifer L. Beverly},   note = {R Package version xxx},   year = {2024},   url = {https://github.com/heyairf/fireexposuR}, }

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT goal fireexposuR provide standardized accessible platform computation analysis wildfire exposure. Wildfire exposure assessments decision support tool wildfire management can applied multiple temporal horizons spatial extents. package automates methods previously documented series scientific publications. Introduces wildfire exposure wildfire transmission distances community scale assessments Validation wildfire exposure metric landscape scale observed fire history Directional vulnerability assessment methodology functions package require pre-preparation data; accompanying paper (currently preparation) details suggestions data acquisition preparation accordance various budget limitations user experience levels. initial release package provides collection functions assist users conducting wildfire exposure directional vulnerability assessments values landscapes, includes methods validating metric area interest. Outputs functions include spatial data, tables, graphics, maps can analyzed modified directly R exported use applications.

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: can install development version fireexposuR GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("heyairf/fireexposuR")

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: basic example shows workflow assess wildfire exposure landscape within area interest.

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: First, example data generated:
code: library(fireexposuR)  # load terra for spatial data funtions library(terra) #> terra 1.7.83  # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # read example polygon geometry for area of interest boundary geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # use geometry to make an area of interest polygon aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: haz layer binary raster represents wildland fuels potential generate embers distance 500 meters value 1.

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: aoi layer polygon representing localized area interest (e.g., built environment community, sensitive habitat, campground, etc.) shown red.

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: Now, use hazard data compute exposure long-range ember transmission.
code: library(fireexposuR) exposure <- fire_exp(hazard, tdist = "l")

title: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure
text: exposure raster rest package functions can used visualize different ways. landscape, can map exposure continuous scale fire_exp_map_cont():  can also see exposure distributed within localized area interest exposure classifications using fire_exp_map_class(). Now can see within area interest northwest corner potential entry point long-range embers landscape. Note: imaginary area interest middle Pacific Ocean base map provide reference.
code: fire_exp_map_cont(exposure) fire_exp_map_class(exposure, classify = "local", aoi)

what: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
text: fire_exp() returns SpatRaster wildfire exposure values calculated using input hazard fuel raster.

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
code: fire_exp(hazard, tdist = c("l", "s", "r"), nonburnable)

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
text: hazard SpatRaster represents hazardous fuels transmission distance specified tdist tdist character vector, can : "l" long-range embers (Default), "s" short-range embers , "r" radiant heat nonburnable (optional) SpatRaster represents non-burnable landscape. cells receive wildfire (e.g. open water, rock) cells natural (e.g. built environment, irrigated agricultural areas) value 1, cells NODATA. parameter provided preparing data fire_exp_validate()

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
text: SpatRaster object exposure values 0-1

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT minimum raster resolution requirements transmission distance. Radiant heat requires data 10 m finer, short-range embers 90 m finer, long-range embers requires 150 m finer. #' fire_exp() computes wildfire exposure metric hazard fuel raster. hazard fuel raster must prepared user. Forbes Beverly 2024 (manuscript preparation) details suggestions data acquisition preparation accordance various budget limitations user experience levels. Computing wildfire exposure different transmission distances may require unique hazard rasters distance. See Beverly et al. 2021, Beverly et al. 2010, Schmidt et al. 2024 references hazard raster preparation.

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric — fire_exp
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # compute long range exposure exposure <- fire_exp(hazard, tdist = "l") #> Warning: RGL: unable to open X11 display #> Warning: 'rgl.init' failed, will use the null device. #> See '?rgl.useNULL' for ways to avoid this warning. exposure #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 321, 321, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 100, 100  (x, y) #> extent      : 384000, 416100, 6033900, 6066000  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : NAD83 / Alberta 10-TM (Forest) (EPSG:3400)  #> source(s)   : memory #> varname     : hazard  #> name        : exposure  #> min value   :        0  #> max value   :        1   # each transmission distance has a resolution requirement and fire_exp() will # not run if resolution is too coarse try(fire_exp(hazard, tdist = "r")) #> Error in fire_exp(hazard, tdist = "r") :  #>   Insufficient resolution for radiant heat exposure assessment

what: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
text: advanced users. Adjust transmission distances defaults used fire_exp().

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
code: fire_exp_adjust(hazard, tdist, nonburnable)

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
text: hazard SpatRaster represents hazardous fuels transmission distance specified tdist tdist Numeric, transmission distance meters nonburnable (Optional)  SpatRaster represents non-burnable landscape. cells receive wildfire (e.g. open water, rock) cells natural (e.g. built environment, irrigated agricultural areas) value 1, cells NODATA. parameter provided preparing data fire_exp_validate()

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
text: SpatRaster object exposure values

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT transmission distances wildfire exposure literature representative wildland fuels area interest, function can used change transmission distance custom distance. highly recommended exposure layers produced function validated observed fire history using fire_exp_validate() function.

title: Compute the wildfire exposure metric with custom transmission distances — fire_exp_adjust
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # compute long range exposure with custom disance of 800 m exposure800 <- fire_exp_adjust(hazard, tdist = 800)

what: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: fire_exp_dir() returns SpatVector linear transects toward value. Transects assessed viable wildfire pathways intersecting areas high exposure.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
code: fire_exp_dir(   exposure,   value,   lengths = c(5000, 5000, 5000),   interval = 1,   thresh_exp = 0.6,   thresh_viable = 0.8,   table = FALSE )

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: exposure SpatRaster (e.g. fire_exp()) value Spatvector value point simplified polygon lengths (Optional) vector three numeric values. length transect starting value meters. default c(5000, 5000, 5000). interval (Optional) Numeric. degree interval draw transects analysis. Can one 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10. default 1. thresh_exp (optional) Numeric. exposure value use define high exposure proportion. Must 0-1. default 0.6. thresh_viable (optional) Numeric. minimum intersection transect high exposure patch defined viable pathway proportion. Must 0-1. default 0.8. table Boolean, TRUE: returns table instead feature. default FALSE.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: SpatVector transects attributes: 'deg' = degree, 'seg' = segment, 'viable'. transects returned CRS input features. table = TRUE: data frame returned instead additional attribute 'wkt', Well Known Text (WKT) string transect geometries (coordinate reference system: WGS84).

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: fire_exp_dir() automates directional vulnerability assessment methods documented Beverly Forbes (2023).

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: inputs exposure value layer must coordinate reference system (CRS) defined. transects returned CRS inputs. function draws transects calculating end point transect finding shortest path along WGS84 (EPSG:4326) ellipsoid given bearing distance. value input reprojected input CRS latitude longitude using WGS84 calculations. transects created, projected match CRS input exposure value layer. lengths projected transects effected scale factor input CRS; however, geodesic lengths maintained.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: value feature can provided point simplified polygon. using point feature analysis can sensitive placement point. example, using point represent large town point placed centroid likely different outputs point placed edge community due arrangement lower exposure values typical built environment. option use simplified polygon added function values may large represent single point. polygon drawn consideration following function able run. polygon must single part polygon holes. polygon smooth simple shape, ideally circular ellipsoidal. polygon also approximate radius less 5000 meters center. area interest larger consider using multiple assessments.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: default values based methods used validated Alberta, Canada Beverly Forbes (2023). Options added function allow values adjusted user required. Adjusting values can lead unexpected uncertain results.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: drawing transects can customized varying intervals segment lengths desired. Adjustments interval lengths parameters effect much exposure data captured transects. parameters adjusted trigonometry might required find optimal combination parameters ensure distances transects make sense intended application. resolution exposure raster may also factor decisions.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: interval parameter defines many transects drawn. default 1 draws transect every whole degree 1-360. outputs total 1080 transects, 360 segment. Increasing interval output less transects process faster. interval increased, distance ends transects also increased. example: terminus 15000 meter transects (default) drawn every 1 degree (default) approximately 250 meters apart, drawn 10 degree intervals approximately 2500 meters apart. Larger intervals increase speed processing time, might capture potential pathways transects farther value.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: lengths parameters allows custom distance defined three transect segments meters. Lengths can increased decreased. segments can also different lengths desired.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: Threshold adjustments considered validation within area interest done. function fire_exp_validate() included package make process easier, still requires significant time, data, understanding.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: thresh_exp parameter can adjusted define minimum exposure value considered directional assessment. default value 0.6 based findings Beverly et al. (2021) showed observed fires burned preferentially areas wildfire exposure values exceed 60%. Adjusting value recommended validation wildfire exposure conducted area interest.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: thresh_viable parameter defines minimum intersection high exposure areas considered viable pathway. default value 0.8 determined Beverly Forbes (2023) drawing continuous linear transects within burned areas represent observed pathways. found average intersection patches pre-fire high exposure 80%. methodology repeated users area interest.

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
text: Beverly JL, Forbes (2023) Assessing directional vulnerability wildfire. Natural Hazards 117, 831-849. DOI Beverly JL, McLoughlin N, Chapman E (2021) simple metric landscape fire exposure. Landscape Ecology 36, 785-801. DOI

title: Conduct a directional exposure assessment — fire_exp_dir
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate an example point point_wkt <- "POINT (400000 6050000)" point <- terra::vect(point_wkt, crs = hazard)  # compute exposure metric exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  # assess directional exposure fire_exp_dir(exposure, point) #>  class       : SpatVector  #>  geometry    : lines  #>  dimensions  : 1080, 3  (geometries, attributes) #>  extent      : 385010.1, 414989.5, 6035010, 6064990  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #>  coord. ref. : NAD83 / Alberta 10-TM (Forest) (EPSG:3400)  #>  names       :   deg   seg viable #>  type        : <num> <chr>  <num> #>  values      :     1  seg1      0 #>                    1  seg2      1 #>                    1  seg3      0

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: fire_exp_dir_map() plots directional exposure transects onto map.

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
code: fire_exp_dir_map(   transects,   value,   zoomlevel = 11,   labels,   title = "Directional Vulnerability" )

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: transects SpatVector. Output fire_exp_dir() value (Optional) SpatVector. Adds value map. Use value feature used generate transects fire_exp_dir() zoomlevel (Optional). Numeric. set zoom level base map tile. See details. default 11. labels (Optional) vector three strings. Custom formatting distances legend. left blank, function automatically label distances meters. title (Optional) String. custom title plot. default "Directional Vulnerability"

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: map directional exposure transects ggplot object

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: function returns standardized map basic cartographic elements. plot returned ggplot object can exported/saved multiple image file formats.

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: function dynamically pulls map tiles base map. inputs projected WGS 84/Pseudo-Mercator (EPSG:3857) align map tiles.

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
text: map tile zoom level may need adjusted. base map blurry, increase zoom level. Higher zoom levels slow function, increase necessary. Reference OpenStreetMap Wiki information zoom levels.

title: Map directional exposure — fire_exp_dir_map
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate an example point point_wkt <- "POINT (400000 6050000)" point <- terra::vect(point_wkt, crs = hazard)  # compute exposure metric exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  # generate transects transects <- fire_exp_dir(exposure, point)  # map with customized distance labels fire_exp_dir_map(transects, labels = c("5 km", "10 km", "15 km"),                  zoomlevel = 9)

title: Summarize or plot directional load for multiple values — fire_exp_dir_multi
text: exposure SpatRaster fire_exp() values Spatvector value point simplified polygon plot Boolean, TRUE: returns standardized directional plot. default FALSE. Boolean, TRUE: considers 3 segments (0-15km) directional transects. FALSE: segments 5-15 km included (Default)

title: Summarize or plot directional load for multiple values — fire_exp_dir_multi
text: data.frame features attributes: value featureID, degree, to5 (binary), to10(binary), t015(binary), full(binary), outer (binary). Unless: * plot = TRUE: standardized plot ggplot object

title: Summarize or plot directional load for multiple values — fire_exp_dir_multi
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT

title: Summarize or plot directional load for multiple values — fire_exp_dir_multi
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate 10 random example points within the hazard extent e <- terra::buffer(terra::vect(terra::ext(hazard), crs = hazard), -15500) points <- terra::spatSample(e, 10)  # compute exposure metric exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  # plot directional load for multiple points fire_exp_dir_multi(exposure, points, plot = TRUE)

title: Plot directional exposure in a radial plot — fire_exp_dir_plot
text: transects SpatVector (output fire_exp_dir()) labels (Optional) vector three strings. Custom formatting distance labels transect segments. left blank, function automatically label distances meters. title (Optional) String. custom title plot. default "Directional Vulnerability"

title: Plot directional exposure in a radial plot — fire_exp_dir_plot
text: ggplot object.

title: Plot directional exposure in a radial plot — fire_exp_dir_plot
text: radial plot produced function based figures presented Beverly Forbes (2023). plots put transect origin (value) center point, labels distances value end transect segments. value used generate transects polygon feature, transect origins still drawn center point. plot returned ggplot object can exported/saved multiple image file formats.

title: Plot directional exposure in a radial plot — fire_exp_dir_plot
text: Beverly JL, Forbes (2023) Assessing directional vulnerability wildfire. Natural Hazards 117, 831-849. DOI

title: Plot directional exposure in a radial plot — fire_exp_dir_plot
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate an example point point_wkt <- "POINT (400000 6050000)" point <- terra::vect(point_wkt, crs = hazard)  # compute exposure metric exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  # generate transects transects <- fire_exp_dir(exposure, point)   # radial plot fire_exp_dir_plot(transects)   # customize labels fire_exp_dir_plot(transects, labels = c("5 km", "10 km", "15 km"))

title: Extract exposure values to features — fire_exp_extract
text: exposure SpatRaster (e.g. fire_exp()) values Spatvector points polygons

title: Extract exposure values to features — fire_exp_extract
text: SpatVector object new attributes

title: Extract exposure values to features — fire_exp_extract
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT Values can provided either points polygons, must singlepart features (.e. attribute table one row per value). values polygon features maximum mean exposure computed.

title: Extract exposure values to features — fire_exp_extract
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate example area of interest geometry geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR")) aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)  # generate random points within the aoi polygon points <- terra::spatSample(aoi, 100)  # compute exposure exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  fire_exp_extract(exposure, points) #>  class       : SpatVector  #>  geometry    : points  #>  dimensions  : 100, 1  (geometries, attributes) #>  extent      : 398037.5, 401850.2, 6048781, 6051320  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #>  coord. ref. : NAD83 / Alberta 10-TM (Forest) (EPSG:3400)  #>  names       : exposure #>  type        :    <num> #>  values      :   0.2625 #>                  0.7375 #>                  0.6875

what: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis

title: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis
code: fire_exp_extract_vis(   values_ext,   method = c("max", "mean"),   classify = c("local", "landscape"),   map = FALSE )

title: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis
text: values_ext Spatvector points polygons fire_exp_extract() method character, either "max" "mean". values_ext polygons default "max".parameter ignored values_ext point features. classify character, either "local" "landscape" specify classification scheme use. default "local" map Boolean. TRUE, map returned ggplot object. default FALSE.

title: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis
text: summary table returned data frame object, Unless: map = TRUE: ggplot object

title: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT Landscape classification breaks : Low (0-20%) Moderate (20-40%) High (40-60%), High (60-80%) Extreme (80-100%) Local classification breaks : Nil (0%) Low (>0-15%) Moderate (15-30%) High (30-45%) Extreme (45%+)

title: Summarize or plot exposure to values — fire_exp_extract_vis
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate example area of interest geometry geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR")) aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)  # generate random points within the aoi polygon points <- terra::spatSample(aoi, 200)  # compute exposure exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  values_exp <- fire_exp_extract(exposure, points)  # summarize example points in a table fire_exp_extract_vis(values_exp, classify = "local") #>   scale method    class   n  prop #> 1 local  Point      Nil   1 0.005 #> 2 local  Point      Low   5 0.025 #> 3 local  Point Moderate  27 0.135 #> 4 local  Point     High  34 0.170 #> 5 local  Point  Extreme 133 0.665  # visualize example points in standardized map fire_exp_extract_vis(values_exp, map = TRUE)

Defaults : classify = "local" zoom level default 13 classify = "landscape" zoom level default 6

Scales colors determined parameter classify can set "local" "landscape". Landscape classification breaks : Low (0-20%) Moderate (20-40%) High (40-60%), High (60-80%) Extreme (80-100%) Local classification breaks : Nil (0%) Low (>0-15%) Moderate (15-30%) High (30-45%) Extreme (45%+)

title: Map exposure with a classified scale — fire_exp_map_class
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate example area of interest geometry geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR")) aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)  # compute exposure exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  fire_exp_map_class(exposure, classify = "local", aoi)

title: Summarize exposure by class — fire_exp_summary
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # read example area of interest polygon geometry geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR")) aoi <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard)  # Compute exposure exposure <- fire_exp(hazard)  # Summary for full extent of data fire_exp_summary(exposure, classify = "landscape") #>       class npixels      prop    aream2 areaha #> 1       Low   14187 0.1466796 141870000  14187 #> 2  Moderate   13073 0.1351620 130730000  13073 #> 3      High   15105 0.1561708 151050000  15105 #> 4 Very High   18911 0.1955211 189110000  18911 #> 5   Extreme   35445 0.3664664 354450000  35445  # Summary masked to an area of interest fire_exp_summary(exposure, aoi, classify = "landscape") #>       class npixels       prop  aream2 areaha #> 1       Low      57 0.06761566  570000     57 #> 2  Moderate     172 0.20403321 1720000    172 #> 3      High     207 0.24555160 2070000    207 #> 4 Very High     330 0.39145907 3300000    330 #> 5   Extreme      77 0.09134045  770000     77

what: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
text: advanced users. fire_exp_validate() compares proportion exposure classes study area proportion exposure classes within burned areas. random sample taken account spatial autocorrelation.

title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
code: fire_exp_validate(   burnableexposure,   fires,   aoi,   samplesize = 0.005,   plot = FALSE )

title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
text: burnableexposure SpatRaster exposure, non-burnable cells removed using optional parameter fire_exp(). fires SpatVector observed fire perimeters aoi (Optional) SpatVector delineates area interest samplesize Proportion area sample. default 0.005 (0.5%) plot Boolean, TRUE: returns plot expected observed exposure class proportions within entire extent sampled areas. default FALSE.

title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
text: table plot

title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
text: DOCUMENTATION DEVELOPMENT

title: Validate exposure with observed fires — fire_exp_validate
code: # read example hazard data hazard_file_path <- "extdata/hazard.tif" hazard <- terra::rast(system.file(hazard_file_path, package = "fireexposuR"))  # generate example non-burnable cells data geom_file_path <- "extdata/polygon_geometry.csv" geom <- read.csv(system.file(geom_file_path, package = "fireexposuR")) polygon <- terra::vect(as.matrix(geom), "polygons", crs = hazard) no_burn <- terra::rasterize(polygon, hazard)  # generate example fire polygons by buffering random points points <- terra::spatSample(terra::rescale(hazard, 0.8),                             30, as.points = TRUE) fires <- terra::buffer(points, 800) # PLEASE NOTE THIS RANDOMLY GENERATED DATA DOES NOT GIVE MEANINGFUL RESULTS  # compute exposure and remove non-burnable cells exposure <- fire_exp(hazard, nonburnable = no_burn)  # results as table fire_exp_validate(exposure, fires) #>    exposure  classexp     of    group     n       prop #> 1         1       Low  Total Expected 14143 0.14741505 #> 2         2  Moderate  Total Expected 12922 0.13468835 #> 3         3      High  Total Expected 14912 0.15543048 #> 4         4 Very High  Total Expected 18595 0.19381905 #> 5         5   Extreme  Total Expected 35368 0.36864707 #> 6         1       Low  Total Observed   677 0.09929598 #> 7         2  Moderate  Total Observed   600 0.08800235 #> 8         3      High  Total Observed  1246 0.18275154 #> 9         4 Very High  Total Observed  1513 0.22191258 #> 10        5   Extreme  Total Observed  2782 0.40803755 #> 11        1       Low Sample Expected    75 0.15625000 #> 12        2  Moderate Sample Expected    67 0.13958333 #> 13        3      High Sample Expected    66 0.13750000 #> 14        4 Very High Sample Expected    85 0.17708333 #> 15        5   Extreme Sample Expected   187 0.38958333 #> 16        1       Low Sample Observed     5 0.14705882 #> 17        2  Moderate Sample Observed     3 0.08823529 #> 18        3      High Sample Observed    10 0.29411765 #> 19        4 Very High Sample Observed     5 0.14705882 #> 20        5   Extreme Sample Observed    11 0.32352941  # results as bar chart fire_exp_validate(exposure, fires, plot = TRUE)

what: fireexposuR: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure — fireexposuR-package
title: fireexposuR: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure — fireexposuR-package
text: package computes wildfire exposure using methods Beverly et al. (2010), Beverly et al. (2021), Beverly Forbes (2023). provides functions standardize mapping visualization wildfire exposure. package requires pre-processing data docomented Forbes Beverly (preparation).

title: fireexposuR: Compute and Visualize Wildfire Exposure — fireexposuR-package
text: Maintainer: Air Forbes amforbes@ualberta.ca (ORCID) contributors: Jennifer Beverly [thesis advisor]
